## HTML5 Basic Tags and Structure ### Introduction HTML5 is the latest version of Hypertext Markup Language, which is used to structure and present content on the web. It introduces new features and elements that enhance the capabilities of web pages. This documentation provides an overview of the basic tags and structure in HTML5. ### Objective and Scope The objective of this documentation is to familiarize users with the basic tags and structure in HTML5. It covers the essential elements required to create a well-structured HTML document. The scope of this documentation includes an explanation of each tag and its usage. ### Requirements and Pre-requisites To follow along with this documentation, you will need a text editor and a web browser. No prior knowledge of HTML is required. ### Step-by-Step Instructions 1. Create a new HTML file using a text editor. 2. Start with the `` declaration, which tells the browser that the document is an HTML5 document. 3. Add the opening and closing `` tags to enclose the entire document. 4. Inside the `` tags, add the `` and `` tags. 5. The `` tag contains meta-information about the document and is not displayed on the web page. Add the `` tag within the `<head>` tag to specify the title of the document. 6. Inside the `<body>` tag, you can add content that will be displayed on the web page. 7. Use the `<h1>` to `<h6>` tags to define headings of different levels. The `<h1>` tag represents the main heading, while `<h2>` to `<h6>` represent subheadings. 8. Use the `<p>` tag to define paragraphs of text. 9. Use the `<a>` tag to create hyperlinks. The `href` attribute specifies the URL that the link points to. 10. Use the `<img>` tag to insert images into the web page. The `src` attribute specifies the source URL of the image. 11. Use the `<ul>` and `<li>` tags to create unordered lists. The `<ul>` tag represents the entire list, while the `<li>` tags represent individual list items. 12. Use the `<ol>` and `<li>` tags to create ordered lists. The `<ol>` tag represents the entire list, while the `<li>` tags represent individual list items. 13. Use the `<table>` tag to create tables. The `<tr>` tag represents a table row, while the `<td>` tag represents a table cell. 14. Use the `<div>` tag to group elements together and apply styles using CSS. 15. Use the `<span>` tag to apply styles to a specific section of text within a paragraph. 16. Use the `<form>` tag to create forms for user input. The `action` attribute specifies the URL to which the form data will be submitted. 17. Use the `<input>` tag to create input fields within a form. The `type` attribute specifies the type of input field (e.g., text, checkbox, radio, etc.). 18. Use the `<button>` tag to create buttons within a form. 19. Save the HTML file with a .html extension. 20. Open the HTML file in a web browser to view the web page. ### Code Snippets and Commands Here are some code snippets that demonstrate the usage of the basic tags in HTML5: ```html <!DOCTYPE html> <html> <head> <title>My Web Page

Welcome to My Web Page

This is a paragraph of text.

Click here to visit a website.
  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Item 3
  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2
  3. Item 3
Cell 1 Cell 2
Cell 3 Cell 4

This is a div element.

This is a red word.

``` ### Troubleshooting and Common Issues - Make sure all tags are properly opened and closed. - Check for any syntax errors in the HTML code. - Ensure that file paths for images and external resources are correct. - Use the browser's developer tools to inspect and debug any issues. ### Best Practices and Recommendations - Use proper indentation and formatting to make the HTML code more readable. - Use semantic HTML tags to convey the meaning of the content. - Separate the structure (HTML), presentation (CSS), and behavior (JavaScript) of a web page. - Use external CSS and JavaScript files for better maintainability. - Optimize images for web to improve page load times. - Test your web page on different browsers and devices for cross-compatibility. ### Summary and Conclusion HTML5 provides a set of basic tags and structure to create well-structured web pages. This documentation covered the essential tags and their usage. By following the step-by-step instructions and best practices, you can create HTML5 documents that are both functional and visually appealing.
